sub_topic: Prove that every group of order 30 is isomorphic to either the cyclic group C30, the dihedral group D15, or the non-abelian group of order 30.
message_1: Let G be a group of order 30. If G is isomorphic to either the cyclic group C30 or the dihedral group D15, how many distinct subgroups of order 5 does G have?
message_2:
If G is isomorphic to the cyclic group C30, then G has a unique subgroup of order 5. This is because a cyclic group of order n has exactly one subgroup of order d for each divisor d of n. In this case, the divisors of 30 are 1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 10, 15, and 30. So, there is only one subgroup of order 5 in C30.

If G is isomorphic to the dihedral group D15, then G has two distinct subgroups of order 5. The dihedral group D15 has order 2 * 15 = 30 and consists of the symmetries of a regular 15-gon, including rotations and reflections. The rotations form a cyclic subgroup of order 15, which has a unique subgroup of order 5. Additionally, there is another subgroup of order 5 consisting of a reflection and the rotations that are multiples of 3. These two subgroups of order 5 are distinct in D15.

In either case, G has at most two distinct subgroups of order 5. Therefore, G has exactly two distinct subgroups of order 5 when it is isomorphic to the dihedral group D15 and only one when it is isomorphic to the cyclic group C30.
